name: Humaniti
mission: HUMANITI FOUNDATION IS A UNITED STATES NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION WITH THE SPECIFIC, AND PRIMARY PURPOSE TO RAISE FUNDS AND MAKE DISTRIBUTIONS FOR CHARITAB...
theoryOfChange: Humaniti has a published Theory of Change model that aims to explain how the organization achieves impact. This model identifies their pathway to achieving impact through their overall work or specific program interventions. The Theory of Change includes three pathways: strengthening individuals, strengthening networks of local organizations, and strengthening the humanitarian system. These pathways guide Humaniti and its partners to make the most impact and create lasting change, ultimately enabling people to be better prepared and respond to crises in their own countries.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects an <cite id="1">emerging organization</cite> that has established a clear strategy but lacks multi-year external impact evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The foundation utilizes a <cite id="16">clear theory of change</cite> focused on direct provision of health and water services to reduce mortality in crisis zones.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that high program spending translates into actual health and safety improvements for beneficiaries.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: As a new organization with <cite id="4">revenue under $250k</cite> and high grantmaking demand, there is significant capacity to absorb new capital.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by a <cite id="5">95.7% program ratio</cite> which is significantly higher than the <cite id="10">industry standard of 75%</cite>.

strengths.detail: The organization directs a <cite id="5">program expense ratio of 95.7%</cite> toward its mission, significantly exceeding the <cite id="10">peer program ratio median of 89.7%</cite>.
The foundation maintains a <cite id="6">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, ensuring donor contributions are not eroded by solicitation costs.
Humaniti Foundation supports <cite id="9">eight asnaf categories</cite>, including the poor, needy, and those in debt, providing high alignment for faith-based giving.

strengths_deep_dive: Humaniti Foundation's financial model is characterized by extreme directness. In 2023, the organization distributed <cite id="11">$877,690 in total grants</cite>, focusing heavily on medical and humanitarian partnerships. Notable distributions included <cite id="12">$500,000 to Fajr Scientific</cite> and <cite id="13">$301,600 to Good Gifts</cite>. This grantmaking strategy allows the foundation to leverage specialized partners to deliver <cite id="3">HEAL and Clean Water programs</cite> across <cite id="7">ten countries</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: Founded in <cite id="1">2023</cite>, Humaniti Foundation is a U.S.-based non-profit organization dedicated to <cite id="2">raising funds and making distributions</cite> for global humanitarian relief. Despite its recent establishment, the organization has rapidly developed a diverse portfolio of initiatives, including the <cite id="3">HEAL program, Clean Water projects, and Emergency Relief</cite>. The foundation operates with a lean financial model, reporting <cite id="4">total revenue of $233,066</cite> in its 2023 tax year. A defining characteristic of its operations is its <cite id="5">95.7% program expense ratio</cite>, indicating that all reported expenses were directed toward charitable activities rather than administrative overhead. Furthermore, the organization demonstrates <cite id="6">exceptional fundraising efficiency of $0.00</cite> spent to raise every dollar. Humaniti Foundation maintains a broad geographic reach for an emerging organization, targeting crisis zones such as <cite id="7">Gaza, Sudan, Yemen, and Somalia</cite>. As a <cite id="8">verified Zakat-eligible charity</cite>, it provides a structured platform for Muslim donors to fulfill their religious obligations through programs serving <cite id="9">eight distinct asnaf categories</cite>, including the poor (fuqara) and needy (masakin).
